div.p: THE CITY WIT, OR, The VVoman wears the BREECHES.
LONDON, Printed by T. R. for Richard Marriot, and Thomas Dring, and are to be ſold at their Shops in Fleet-ſtreet, 1653.

div.head: The Prologue.

opener.salute: Quot quot adeſtis, ſalvete, ſalvetote Gentlemen,

div.p:
YOu ſee I come unarm'd among you, ſine Virga aut Ferula, without Rod or Fe|rular, which are the Pedants weapons. Id eſt, that is to ſay, I come not hi|ther to be an Inſtructor to any of you, that were Aquilam volare docere, aut Delphi|num natare, to teach the Ape, well learned as my ſelfe. Nor came I to inſtruct the Comedians. That were for me to be Aſinus inter ſimias, the fool o'the Company: I dare not undertake them. I am no Paedagogus nor Hypodidaſcalus here. I approach not hither ad erudiendum, nec ad Corrigendum. Nay I have given my Schollars leave to play, to get a Vacuum for my ſelfe to day, to Act a particle here in a Play; an Actor being wanting that could beare it with port and state enough. A Pedant is not eaſily imitated. Therefore in perſon, I for your delight have
left my Schoole to tread the Stage. Pray Jove the terror of my brow ſpoile not your mirth, for you can|not forget the fury of a Tutor, when you have layne under the blazing Comet of his wrath, with quaeſo Praeceptor te precor da—&c. But, let feare paſſe, nothing but mirth's intended.
But I had forgot my ſelfe, A Prologue ſhould be in Ryhme, &c. therefore I will begin agen.

lg.l: Kind Gentlemen, and men of gentle kinde,
There is in that a figure, as you'll finde,
Becauſe weeltake your eares as 'twere in Ropes,
Ile nothing ſpeak but figures, ſtrayns & tropes.
The Schoolemaſter that never yet beſought yee,
Is now become a ſuitor, that you'll ſit,
And exerciſe your Judgement with your wit,
On this our Comedy, which in bold Phraſe,
The Author ſayes has paſt with good applauſe
In former times. For it was written, when
It bore juſt Judgement, and the ſeal of Ben.
Some in this round may have both ſeen't, and heard,
Ere I, that beare its title, wore a Beard.
My ſute is therefore that you will not looke,
To find more in the Title then the Booke.
My part the Pedant, though it ſeem a Columne
Is but a Page, compar'd to the whole volume.
What bulk have I to bear a Scene to paſſe,
But by your favours multiplying Glaſſe.
In nova fert Animus, then Ile do my beſt
To gaine your Plaudite among the reſt.
So with the ſalutation I firſt brought yee,

list.item: CRaſy, a young Citizen, falling into decay.

Crack, a Boy that ſings.
two keeping Women.
Iſabell
Jone

div.head: The City VVit. OR, The woman wears the Breeches.
Scene I.
div.stage: A Dinner carryed over the Stage in cove|red Diſhes. Exeunt.
A Table ſet forth with em|pty Mo|ny-bags, Bills, Bonds, & Bookes of accompts, &c.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Will you not go in and dine, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No: I am of other dyet to day.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: The whole company expects you.

lg.l: May they ſit merry with their cheer,
while I feed on this hard meat. And wait
you within: I ſhall not change a trencher.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Alas my good Maſter.

lg.l: Here are the neſts, but all the He takes up the bags.
Birds are flown.
How eaſie a thing it is to be undone,
When credulous Man will truſt his 'ſtate to others!
Am I drawn dry? Not ſo much as the Lees left?
Nothing but empty Cask? have I no refuge
To fly to now? Yes, here, about a groats worth He takes up the bils & papers.
Of paper it was once. Would I had now
Greens groatſ-worth of wit for it. But 'twill ſerve
To light tobacco-pipes. Here (let me ſee)
Here is three hundred pound, two hundred here.
And here one hundred, and two hundred here;
Fifty; fifty; fifty; and one hundred here,
And here one hundred and fifty. Beſides
A many parcells of ſmall debts, which make
Two hundred more. I ſhall not live to tell it,
But put it up, and take it by the weight. He puts the Bills & Bonds into a Bag.
O me! how heavy 'tis! And, doubtleſs, ſo 'twould be
At ſome mans heart. It troubles me a little. Enter Jeremy.
Now what newes?
My miſtriſs, and your Mother Sir,
Intreats you to come to dinner.
Theſe they are; My debts,
That ſtrike me through. This bag will never pay
Any of theſe.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Sir, ſhall I ſay you'l come?

lg.l: How well it were, if any of my Creditors
Could once but dream that this were current mony!

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Even what thou wilt, good Jeremy.

lg.l: Alas you know, this dinner was appointed
A friendly meeting for moſt of your Creditors,
And many of your Debtors.
But I hope
Few of the laſt appeare.
None but ſome priviledg'd Courtiers, that dare
Put in at all mens Tables. They're all ſet,
Your Creditors on one ſide, and your Debtors
On t'other; and do only ſtay for you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: To feed on; do they? Goe. I will not come.

lg.l: I feare, Sir, you will overthrow the good
That was intended you. You know this meeting
Was for the Creditors to give longer day,
As they ſhould find your Debtors to acknowledg
The ſummes they owe you. Sir I ſhould be ſorry
To ſee you ſinck, or forc'd to hide your head,
That look'd as high, as any in the City.
Prithee go in. And if they ſeem to ſtay,
Pray 'em fall too; tell 'em I take this time
Only to order my Accompts, and that as ſoon
As they are full, and fit to talk, I'le come:
Good Jeremie goe.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Introth I pity him—

lg.l: A right good Boy thou art. I think on thee:
What muſt I do now? All I have is loſt,
And what I have not, ſought to be forc'd from me,
I muſt take nimble hold upon Occaſion,
Or lie for ever in the Bankrupt ditch,
Where no man lends a hand to draw one out▪
I will leape over it, or fall bravely in't,
Scorning the Bridge of Baſeneſs, Compoſition,
Which doth infect a City like the Plague,
And teach men Knavery, that were never born to't:
Whereby the Rope-deſerving Raſcall gains
Purple and Furrs, Trappings and golden Chaines.
Baſe Compoſition, baſer far then Want,
Then Beggery, Impriſonment, Slavery:
I ſcorn thee, though thou lov'ſt a Tradeſ-man dearly
And mak'ſt a Chandler Lord of thouſands yearly.
I will have other ayd. How now! Againe?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: O, Sir, you are undone.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Haſt thou no newes, Jeremie?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Alas your Mother Sir—

lg.l: Why what of her?
Is there a Plate loſt, or a 'Poſtle-ſpoon
A China Diſh broke, or an ancient Glaſs,
And ſtain'd with Wine her Damaſque table-cloath?
Or is the Salt faln towards her? What's the matter?
Her miſchievous tongue has over-thrown the good
Was meant to you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Good, good Jeremie?

lg.l: Your Creditors were on a reſolution
To do you good, and madly ſhe oppos'd it,
And with a vehement voyce proclaims you a Beggar;
Says, you have undone her Daughter; that no good
Is fit to be done for you: And ſuch a ſtorm
Of wicked breath—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: She's drunk; Is ſhe not, Jeremie?

lg.l: No Sir, 'tis nothing but her old diſeaſe,
The Tongue-ague, whoſe fit is now got up
To ſuch a height, the Devil cannot lay it.
The learned School-maſter, Mr. Sarpego
Has conjur'd it by all his parts of ſpeech,
His Tropes and Figures; and cannot be heard
I'th furious Tempeſt. All your Creditors
Are gone in Rage; will take their courſe, they ſay.
Some of your Debtors ſtay, I think, to laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now deafeneſs ſeize me. I diſclaime my hea|ring. I defie my audituall part. I renounce mine ears. Miſtris Pyannet, a deſperate Palſey is on thy lips, and an everlaſting Feaver on thy Tongue?

lg.l: What raging Rout hath rent thy reſt;
What Scold hath ſcutch'd thy skonce:

sp.speaker: Sar.

lg.l: I'le breath it to thy bolder breast,
That askst me for the nonce.

sp.p: You underſtand or know, that here hath been a Feaſt made, to take up a ponderous difference be|tween Maſter Sneakup your Father in Law, and your ſelfe Mr. Craſy; and between moſt of your Creditors and Debitors. Food hath been eaten; Wine drunck; Talke paſt; Breath ſpent; Labour loſt: For why? Mi|ſtris Pyannet your Mother in Law, Mr. Sneakups Wife (though ſhee will be call'd by none but her owne name) that woman of an eternall Tongue; that Creature of an everlaſting noyſe; whoſe per|petuall talke is able to deafen a Miller; whoſe diſcourſe is more tedious then a Juſtices Charge; Shee, that will out-ſcold ten carted Bawds, even when ſhe is ſober; and out-chat fifteen Midwives, though fourteen of them be halfe drunk: this Shee-thing hath burſt all. Demoſthenes himſelfe would give her over. Therefore hopeleſs Sarpego is ſilent.

div.stage: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Sir Andrew Ticket, Rufflit, La. Ticket, Joſina, Linſy-Wolſy.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
O, are you here Sir! You have ſpun a fair thred.
Here's much ado, and little help. We can make bolt nor ſhaft, find neither head nor foot in your buſineſs. My daughter and I may both curſe the time, that ever we ſaw the eyes of thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir, you have the civill vertue of Patience in you. Dear Sir hear me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He ſayes he heares thee, and is aſham'd to ſee thee. Haſt not undone our Daughter▪ ſpent her Porti|on; deceiv'd our hopes; waſted thy fortunes; undone thy credite; prov'd Bankrupt?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: All was but my kind heart in truſting, in tru|ſting, Father.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Kind heart! What ſhould Citizens do with kind hearts; or truſting in any thing but God, and ready money?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What would you, dear Father, that I ſhould do now?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Marry depart in peace Sir. Vaniſh in ſilence Sir. I'le take my Daughter home Sir. She ſhall not beg with you Sir. No marry ſhalt thou not; no, 'deed Duck ſhalt thou not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Be yet but pleaſed to anſwer me, good Sir. May not an honeſt man—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Honeſt man! Who the Devill wiſh'd thee to be an honeſt man? Here's my worſhipfull Husband, Mr. Sneakup, that from a Graſier is come to be a Juſtice of Peace: And, what, as an honeſt man? Hee grew to be able to give nine hundred pound with my daughter; and, what, by honeſtie? Mr. Sneakup and I are come up to live i'th City, and here we have lyen theſe three years; and what? for honeſty? Honeſty! What ſhould the City do with honeſty; when 'tis enough to undoe a whole Corporation? Why are your Wares gumm'd; your Shops dark; your Prizes writ in ſtrange Chara|cters? what, for honeſty? Honeſty? why is hard waxe
call'd Merchants waxe; and is ſaid ſeldome or never to be rip'd off, but it plucks the skin of a Lordſhip with it? what! for honeſty? Now (mortified my Concupi|ſcence!) Doſt thou think, that our Neighbour, Maſter Linſy-Wolſie here, from the ſonne of a Tripe-wife, and a Rope-maker, could aſpire to be an Aldermans Depu|ty; to be Worſhipfull Mr. Linſie-Wolſie; Venerable Mr. Linſie-wolſie; to weare Sattin ſleeves, & whip Beg|gars? And, what? By honeſty? Have we bought an Of|fice, here, for our towardly and gracious ſon and heire here, young Mr. Sneakup—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes forſooth Mother.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: And made him a Courtier, in hope of his ho|neſty? Nay, (once for all) Did we marry our Daugh|ter, here, to thee; rack'd our Purſes to pay Portion; left Country houſe-keeping to ſave charges, in hope either of thine, or her honeſty? No, we look'd, that thy Ware-houſe ſhould have eaten up Caſtles, and that for thy narrow Walke in a Jewellers ſhop, a whole Countrey ſhould not have ſuffic'd thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: If my uncunning Diſpoſition be my only vice, then Father—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay, and thou haſt been married three years to my Daughter, and haſt not got her with Child yet! How do'ſt anſwer that? For a woman to be married to a fruitfull Fool, there is ſome bearing with him yet. (I know it by my ſelf) but a dry barren Fool! How doſt thou ſatisfie that?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: It may be defect in your Daughter, as proba|ble as in me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: O impudent varlet! Defect in my Daughter? O horrible indignity! Defect in my Daughter? Nay, 'tis well known, before ever thou ſaweſt her, there was no defect in my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Well: If to be honeſt, be to be a fool, my utmoſt
Ambition is a Coxcomb. Sir, I crave your farewell.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Marry Sir, and have it with all his heart. My Husband is a man of few words, and hath committed his tongue to me: And I hope I ſhall uſe it to his Wor|ſhip. Fare you well Sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thanks for your cheer and full bounty of En|tertainment, good Mr. Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He rather thanks you for your patience, and kind viſitation, good Sir Andrew Ticket. Yes indeed forſooth does he.

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: I take my leave Sir, too.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Good Madame—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Uds ſo! ther's a trick! you muſt talk, muſt you? And your Wife in preſence, muſt you? As if I could not have ſaid, good Madame. Good Madame! Do you ſee how it becomes you?

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Good Miſtris Sneakup▪

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Good Madame, I beſeech your Ladiſhip to ex|cuſe our deficiency of Entertainment. Though ou● power be not to our wiſh, yet we wiſh that our Power were to your Worth, which merrits better ſervice—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Then our rudeneſſe—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: You wrong your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Can tender, or poſſibly expreſſe by—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: I beſeech you forſooth—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Our beſt labour, or utmoſt devoire. Yes I pro|teſt ſweet Madame. I beſeech you, as you paſſe by in Coach ſometimes, vouchſafe to ſee me; and, if I come to Court, I will preſume to viſite your Ladiſhip, and your worthy Knight, Good Sir Andrew! And I pray you Madame, how does your Monckey, your Parrot, and Parraquitoes? I pray commend me to 'em, and to all your little ones. Fare you well, ſweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Wee'll leave you to take private farewell of your Wife, Mr. Craſie.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Wee'l meet you at your Horſe, brother.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Lov'd, my deare heart, my ſweeteſt, my very being, will you needs take your journey? I ſhall fall before your return into a Conſumption. If you die but conceive what your departure will bring upon me, I know (my ſweet) nay I do know—but goe your ways; ſtrike my finger into mine eye: 'Tis not the firſt true teare a married woman has ſhed.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why you heare the noyſe of that woman of Sound, your Mother. I muſt travell down, or not keep up. Yet—

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Nay, goe I beſeech you; you ſhall never ſay, I undid you. Goe I pray: But never look to ſee me my owne woman again. How long will you ſtay forth?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A fortnight at the leaſt; and a moneth at the moſt.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Well, a fortnight at the leaſt. Never woman took a more heavy departure. Kiſſe me. Farewel. Kiſs me againe. I pray does your Horſe amble, or trot? Do not ride poſt as you come home, I pray. Kiſſe me once more. Farewell.
Hay hoe! How I do gape.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What's a clock Bridget.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Paſt three forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Tis paſt ſleeping time then, Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Nothing is paſt to thoſe, that have a mind and means.

lg.l: Thats true and tryed. Go lay my Pillow Bridget. Exit Brid.
Lord, what a thing a woman is in her Husbands ab|ſence!
Waſt thou ever in love, Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Who I forſooth? No forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: I forſooth, and no forſooth? then I perceive you are forſooth. But I adviſe you to take head, how you levell your Affection towards me: I am your Mi|ſtris; And I hope you never heard of any Apprentice was ſo bold with his Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: No indeed forſooth. I ſhould be ſorry there ſhould be any ſuch.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Nay, be not ſorry neither Jeremy. Is thy Ma|ſter gone? Look. A pretty youth, this ſame Jeremy! And is come of a good Race. I have heard my Mother ſay, his Father was a Ferretter—

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: He is gone forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Come hither Jeremy. Doſt thou ſee this Hand|kerchief?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: I vow'd this Handkerchief ſhould never touch any bodies face, but ſuch a one, as I would intreat to lie with me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Indeed forſooth!

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Come hither Jeremy. There's a ſpot o'thy Cheek, let me wipe it off.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: O Lord forſooth. I'le go waſh it.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Heaven made this Boy of a very honeſt Appe|tite, ſober Ignorance, and modeſt Underſtanding. My old Grandmothers Latine is verified upon him; Ars non habet Inimicum praeter Ignorantem. Ignorance is womans greateſt Enemy. Who's within? Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Go your wayes to Miſtreſſe Parmiſan, the Cheeſmongers Wife in old Fiſhſtreet, and commend me to her; and intreat her to pray Miſtreſſe Collifloore the Hearb-woman in the Old Change, that ſhe will de|ſire Miſtris Piccadell in Bow-lane, in any hand to be|ſeech the good old dry Nurſe mother, Et cetera, ſhee knowes where, to provide me an honeſt, handſome, ſecret young man; that can write, and read written hand. Take your errand with you; that can write and read written hand.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I warrant you forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: So, now will I meditate, take a nap, and dreame out a few fancies.

div.head: Sene II.
div.stage: Enter Craſy, booted. Ticket, Rufflit, Tobias Sarpego, Linſy woolſy:

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: WEE take our leaves Mr. Craſy, and wiſh good Journey to you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Farewell good Mr. Craſy.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Adiue Brother.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Iterum iterumque vale.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Heartily Godbuy, good Mr. Craſy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay but Gentlemen: A little of your patience you all know your own Debts, and my almoſt impu|dent neceſſiries, ſatisfie me, that J may diſcharge o|thers. Will you ſuffer me to ſink under my Freenes? ſhall my goodneſſe, and ready Pietie undoe me? Sir Andrew Ticket, you are a profeſt Courtier, and ſhould have a ●ender ſenſe of honor. This is your day of pay|ment for two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Blood of Bacchus, tis true, tis my day, what then? Doſt take me for a Cittizen, that thou thinkeſt I'll keep my day? No, thou'ſt find that I am a Courtier, let my day keep me and 'twill. But doſt heare? Come to the Court. J will not ſay what I will do for thee. But come to the Court. I ow the two hundred pounds: I'll not deny't, if thou ask ſeven years hence for't, fare|well. I ſay no more, but come to the Court, and ſee if I will know thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O, Sir, now you are in favour, you will know no body.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: True: tis juſt. Why ſhould we, when we are in favour know any body; when, if we be in diſgrace, no body will know us? Farewell honeſt Tradeſman.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: That is Synonima for a fool. An ironicall E|pithite, upon my Facunditie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O Maſter Sarpego! I know you will ſatisfie your own driblet of ten pound, I lent you out of my Purſe.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Diogenes Laertius on a certaine time, deman|ding of Cornelius Tacitus an Areopagit of Syracuſa; what was the moſt Commodious and expediteſt me|thod to kill the Itch, anſwered—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Anſwer me my monyes I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Peremptorily, Careo Supinis; I want money. I confeſſe, ſome driblets are in the Debet. But, me
thinks, that you being a Man of Wit, Braine, Forecaſt and Forehead, ſhould not be ſo eaſie, (I will not ſay fooliſh, for that were a figure) as to lend a Philoſo|pher money, that cryes, when he is naked, Omnîa mea mecum porto. Well Sir, J ſhall ever live to wish, that your owne Lanthorne may be your direction; and that, where ever you travell, the Cornu copia of A|bundance may accompany you. Yes ſure shall I. Vive valeque.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why look you Brother, It was thought, that I had a tender Pericranion; or, in direct Phraſe, that I was an unthriſty fool. Signior no: you ſhall now find, that I cannot only keep mine own, but other mens. It is rightly ſaid, He that is poor in Appetite, may quickly be rich in Purſe. Deſire little; covet little; no not your own: And you ſhall have enough.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Enough?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes Brother, litle enough. I confeſſe I am your Debtor for the loane of ſome hundred Marks. Now you have need: who has not? you have need to have it. I have need to pay it. Here's need of all hands. But Brother, you ſhall be no looſer by me. Purchaſe Wit; Get wit (look you) wit. And Brother, if you come to the Court, now my Mother and my Father have bought me an Office there, ſo you will bring my Siſter with you, I will make the beſt ſhew of you that I can. It may chance to ſet you up againe, Brother; tis many an honeſt mans fortune, to riſe by a good Wife. Farewell ſweet Brother. Prithee grow rich againe; and weare good Cloaths, that we may keep our Ac|quaintance ſtill. Farewell, deare Brother. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Mr. Rufflit—

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: VVhat, does thy fiſt gape for mony from me?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I hope it is not the faſhion, for a Gallant of faſhion, to break for ſo ſmall a Portion as the ſumme of an hundred Angells.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: For a Gallant of faſhion to break, for a Gal|lant of faſhion? Doſt thou know what a Gallant of faſhion is? I'll tell thee. It is a thing that but once in three Moneths has money in his Purſe; A creature made up of Promiſe and Proteſtation: A thing that foules other mens Napkins: towſeth other Mens Sheets, flatters all he feares, contemns all he needs not, ſterves all that ſerve him, and undoes all that truſt him. Doſt ask me mony, as I am a Gallant of faſhion, I do thee Curteſie, I beat thee not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I lent it you on your ſingle word.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Tis pittie but thou ſhouldeſt looſe thy Free|dom for it: you Tradeſmen have a good Order in your Citty, Not to lend a Gentleman money without a Cittizen bound with him: But you forſooth ſcorne Orders! By this light, tis pitty thou looſeſt not thy Freedome for it. VVell, when I am fluſh, thou ſhalt feel from mee, Farewell. Prithee learne to have ſome witt. A handſome ſtreight young fellow, grown into a pretty Bear, with a proper bodyed VVoman to his VVife, and cannot beare a Braine! Farewell. Doſt heare? Be rul'd by me, Get money, do, Get money and keep it; wouldſt thrive? Be rather a knave then a Fool. How much doſt ſay I ow thee?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Thou art in my Debt. I have given the Coun|ſell worth threeskore, Dog-cheap, well I'll rent the odde mony.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Strange mad fellows theſe ſame, Mr. Craſie, me thinks to deale withall.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
You are right Mr. Linſie wolſie▪ I would my Genius had directed me, to deale alwayes with ſuch
honeſt neighbourly men as your ſelfe. I hope you will not deny me a Curteſie.

sp.speaker: Linſ.
sp.p: Not I, I proteſt, what is it?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You took once a Jewell of me, which you ſold for thirty pound, for which I have your Bond for ſixty, at your day of mariage. If you will now, becauſe I want preſent money, give me but twenty pound, I'll acquit you.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My good friend Mr. Craſie, I have no tricks and Jerks to come over you, as the witty Gentleman had ere while: But I know a plaine bargaine is a plaine bargaine: and wit is never good till it be bought. If twentie pound will pleaſure you, upon good ſecurity I will procure it you. A hundred if you pleaſe, do you mark Mr. Craſie? On good ſecurity. Otherwiſe you muſt pardon me, Mr. Craſie. I am a poore Tradeſman Mr. Craſie, keep both a Linnen and a VVollen Drapers ſhop, Mr. Craſie, according to my name, Mr. Craſie, and would be loth to lend my money, Mr. Craſie, to be laught at among my Neighbours, Mr. Craſie, as you are Mr. Craſie. And ſo fare you wel, Mr. Craſie.

sp.speaker: Cra.

lg.l: Is this the end of unſuſpicious Freeneſſe?
Are open hands of Chearfull Pietie,
A helpfull bounty, and moſt eaſie Goodneſſe,
Re●arded thus?
Is, to be honeſt, term'd to be a fool?
Reſpect it Heaven. Beare up ſtill merry heart.
Droop not: But ſcorne the worlds unjuſt deſpiſing.

l.hi: Who through Goodneſſe ſinks, his fall's his Riſing.

sp.p: O Maſter, Maſter, upon my knowledge, my Miſtres is forced ſince your departure to be

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Honeſt Sir. Get up your Debts as faſt as you can abroad: For on my underſtanding (which great Iove knowes is but little) ſhee will take up more then your due at home eaſily.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Boy. Didſt never obſerve at the Court gate, that the Lord was no ſooner off from his Horſe-back but the Lackey got up into the Saddle and rode home?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes Sir, tis common.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I ſcorne not my Betters Fortune. And what is not my ſinne, shall never be my shame.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Introth I was faine to make my ſelfe an Aſſe, or elſe I had been tempted to have been a knave.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Boy, thou art now my Prentice. From hence be free. Poverty shall ſerve it ſelfe. Yet do one thing for me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: If it be in the power of my poore Sconce.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If ever it be in thy poſſible ability, wrong all Men, uſe thy wit, to abuſe all things, that have but ſence of wrong: For without mercie, all men have in|jur'd thy miſtruſtles Maſter, Milk'd my thoughts from my heart, and money from my Purſe, and, laſt, laught at my Credulity. Cheat, choſen, live by thy Wits: Tis moſt manly, therefore moſt noble. Horſes get their living by their Backs, Oxen by their necks, Swine and Women by their Fleſh, Only man by his Braine. In briefe be a knave and proſper: For honeſty has beggerd me.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Farewell Maſter. And if I put tricks upon ſome of them, let the end of the Comedie demonſtrate.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd I will revenge. I never provok'd my braine yet. But now if I clap not fire in the tayles of ſome of theſe Samſons Foxes—ſeems my defect of Fortune want of wit? Noe.

lg.l: The ſenſe of our ſlight ſports confeſſ'd ſhall have,
That any may be rich, will be a knave.

div.head: Scene I.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: EGregious and moſt great of Expectation, my right dignified and truly Cice●onian Pupill, now that I have brought you into the Amoene fields with my ready thankfullneſſe for the loane of this ten pound, I commit you to the grace of Court.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I ſhall expect that money ſhortly. Care to ſend it; For I purchaſ'd my place at a rack'd recom|pence.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Your Sarpego is no ſlipperie Companion. You know I am to marry, and this money ſhall provide me Complements.
sp.quote: Sis bonus o faelixque tuis. I pede fausto.

div.stage: Enter Craſy like a lame Souldier.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Belov'd of Phoebus, Minion of the Muſes, deare Water Bayley of Helicon, let it not be diſtaſt|full to thy Divine eares, to receive the humble Petiti|on of a poore Creature, made miſerable by the policie of Providence. That thy rare and abſolute Mu●●fi|cence might ſupply what fortune had l●ſt defective: I kiſſe thy learned toes.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I tell thee, by the Axiomes of the Peripateticall Ariſtotle, thou art a Monſter. My reward shall be therefore like thy ſelfe, monſtrouſly lame. This is a figure in Eloquution call'd Apoxegeſis.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I am not fed with Figures Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You are an idle vagabond, and lye in wait for the blood of the learned. Labour, and live.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Right eloquent and well-phraſed Sir, my edu|cation has been liberall. I ſometimes fed my flock on horned Parnaſſus: But my wants forc'd me to my Sword.

div.stage: He ſhews his blade halfe way.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You did peradventure ſip on the top of Science, Primoribus labijs, or ſo, but did not convert it in Suc|cum & ſanguinem.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: That I may ever remaine a true man—Extend.

The Sun, Moon and the ſeven Planets are my invoked witneſſes, I should be grieved, that neceſſity should make me grow violent on ſo adored, adorned Gramma|ticall Diſciplinary—Be gracious in Contribution—Sir—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: J will give thee an infinite treaſure. Sis integer vitae, ſceleriſque purus. Vale poore Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir, this Sword can bite—But, J know you had rather give it freely out of your own Proclivitie.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes I proteſt, as I am Erudite. Here dreadfull Mavortian, the poor price of a Dinner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If I might in modeſty importune the poore price of a Supper too.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I do ſpeak it in the Optative Mood, I do wish it lay in the modell of my Fortune to give harbour to your shaken ſtate, yet receive this with appeaſed clutch.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
If I might not ſeem audacious even to impu|dence, I poore Freshman in Literature, would implore
of your well-ſalted, & beſt ſeaſon'd vertue, ſome larger allowance to ſupply my defects of Rayment, Books, and other neceſſaries: which magnificence shall ever intitle you, my moſt bounteous Macaenas. Be induc'd to it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar:
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, that you may know how deare you are to me; Know this is more then uſuall largeſſe—for non omnibus dormio—There's a Figure too.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O yes Sir, I underſtand this Figure too very well. Now deare Mecenas, let me implore a Purſe to incloſe theſe Monyes in—Nay if you impart not with a chearfull forhead, Sir

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Vae miſero mihi! ſweet Purſe adieu. Iterum ite|rumque vale.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: May you be importun'd to do it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You shall have it inſtantly. I will only deprome, or take out a little ſtuffing firſt.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Tis no matter. As it is, As it is, good Sir, as it is. Jle accept it as it is. Moſt fragrant-phraſed Ma|ſter, ſuffer thy ſelfe ●o be intreated. Doe—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You have moſt powerfully perſwaded: Take it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Moſt exorbitantly bounteous Mecenas, you have given me all this, have you not?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and you have taken all that, have you not?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but as your gift. Iove bleſſe thy browes, and make cleer thy Phiſnomy. Vale. Your learned Worſhip ſtincks.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Now Barbariſme, Incongruity, and falſe Orthography shame thee; The curſe of Priſcian take thee. All the parts of ſpeech
defie thee. All the Interjections of ſorrow, as Heu hei▪ of Shunning, as Apage; of Diſdaining, as Hem vah; of Scorning, as Hui; of Exclaiming, as Proh Deum at|que hominum fidem take thee. My deare Pupils lend|ings haſt thou lewdly lick'd away: And ſorrowfull Sarpego is lick'd dry. There's a figure left yet! But ô thou Caſtalion Traytor, Pick-purſe of Parnaſſus, and Hang-man of Helicon: Dives thirſt in thy Throat; Ix|ions wheel on thy back; Tantalus hunger in thy guts; and Siſyphus ſtone in thy Bladder.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O fearfull curſe! Well; I haye given my firſt pinch, and a little ſcratch'd my Goat-bearded Gram|marian, that Broke jeſts on my uncunning eaſineſs. But he with the reſt shall feele, that modeſt Simplicity is not alwayes a defect of wit, but will: What my willing honeſty hath ſeem'd to looſe, my affected deceits shall recover. I'le rid 'em one after another, like Guts, till they shall ſtink worſe then Jewes.

lg.l: And they shall find with moſt ashamed eyes,
The honeſt Breaſt lives only rich and wiſe.

sp.speaker: JOſ.
sp.p: Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Bridget, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here, Lady.

lg.l: That's comfortably ſpoken! Nay bluſh not:
We women can never have too much given us. And
Madame▪ Joſina would ſound well.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Madame Joſina Craſie.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: No; not Craſie; hang Craſie: Craſie is my Huſ|bands name. I wonder why Women muſt be called by their Husbands names, I.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O, they muſt forſooth.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: And why not men by their Wives?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Marrie forſooth, becauſe that Men, when they marry, become but halfe men: And the other half goes to their Wives. And therefore ſhe is called Woman; where before ſhe was call'd but Mayd.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Is a married Man but halfe a Man? what is his other halfe then?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Truly, oftentimes, Beaſt. Which part the wife gives to boot, in exchange of her name. One knocks.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Heark, ſome body knocks; goe ſee. What ſhould any body knock at my Garden door for? I doe not uſe to be viſited in my Garden.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Yonders a Gentleman craves admittance to converſe with you.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: I'le converſe with no Gentleman. What have I to do with Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: A fair-ſpoken, comely, modeſt Gentleman he is.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Is he ſo? I'le ſpeak with no modeſt Gentleman▪ You were beſt be his Bawd. But are you ſure he is a true Gentleman? does he weare clean Linnen, and lack Money?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here he comes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: He is very confident, and forward, me thinks.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Exquiſite; very Elixir of Beauty, vouchſafe to receive the tender of my Faith to you; which I proteſt is zealouſly devoted to your particular ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: You may ſpeak lowder Sir: for I aſſure you, my Mayd is very thick of hearing, and exceeding weake ſighted.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then, Lady, let it be ſpoken in bold phraſe, I love you.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. How ſhould I ſtile you, pray?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
My name is Pulſe-feel: A poor Doctor of Phy|ſick, that weares three-pile velvet in his Cap; has paid a quarters rent of his houſe afore-hand; and as meanly as he ſtands here, was made Doctor beyond the Seas. I vow (as I am right Worſhipfull) the taking of my Degree coſt me twelve French crowns, and five and thirty pound of ſalt Butter in upper Germany. I can make your beauty, and preſerve it; Rectifie your Body, and maintain it; perfume your skin; tinct your haire; enliven your Eye; Heighten your Appetite. As for Gel|lies, Dentifrices, Diets, Minerall Fucuſſes, Pomatums, Fumes, Italian Masks to ſleep in, either to moyſten, or
dry the Superficies of your face; paugh, Gallen was a Gooſe, and Paracelſus a Patch to Doctor Pulſe-feel▪ Make me then happy, deare ſweeting, in your private ●avours: The which I vow with as much ſecrefie, conſtancie and Reſolution, to preſerve, as you, with Bounty, ſweetneſſe and Freenes ſhall impart.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: I proteſt you ſpeak very farre within me; I re|ſpect you moſt affectionatly.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then Ile attend you at your Chamber: where the beſt pleaſure, youth, Cupid can miniſter ſhall en|tertaine you.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Entertain me with pleaſure? what pleaſure I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nothing but kiſſe you Lady, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Well, for kiſſing and ſo forth, I care not; But look for no diſhoneſty at my hands, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will be provident.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: And honeſt, I beſeech you: And ſecret, and re|ſolute, I adviſe you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: And very chaſt I command you. But a kiſſe, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I underſtand you. This be my pledg of faith.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: And this of mine.—The thought of me reſt with you. And heare you Doctor; I prithee pro|cure me ſome young Fellow, that can write: For I am ſo troubled with Letters, that I neither read nor an|ſwer—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Rely upon me. I can fit you rarely. I know a well qualified fellow, that danceth rarely, playes on di|vers
Inſtruments, and withall is cloſe.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: I marry, Cloſe! Pray let me have him. Kiſſe and adiew.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will maintain it. He only, that knows it, per|mits, and procures it, is truly a Cuckold. Some fellow would be divorc'd now. Craſie, ſpeak; wilt be di|vorc'd? why, what and I were? why then thou art an Aſſe, Craſie. Why Sir? why Sir! why prithee tell me, what would thy Divorce hurt her? It would but give her more liberty. Shee ſhould have bounteous Cu|ſtomers; Gallants, that would hoiſt her tires, beſtow deep on her. And ſhe ſhould be paid for't. You ſpeak ſomewhat to the matter Sir. Nay Craſie, believe it, though ſhe be not a very modeſt woman for a Wife, thou mayſt force her to be a reaſonable private wench for a Whore. Say you ſo? Birlady, and I'le take your Counſell. 'Tis a pretty Drabb. I know not where to compaſſe ſuch another? troth Sir, I'le follow your ad|vice.

lg.l: And, if my hopes prove not extreamly ill,
I'le keep her fleſh chaſt, though againſt her will.
He tooke her by the middle ſo ſmall
And laid her on the Plain:
And when he had his will on her,
He tooke her up againe.
And what was ſhe then the worſe for wearing?
Can you tell Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Crac:
sp.p: One Sir (I dare tell you in private) that can conduct you to a more lovely Creature, then her you laſt courted.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: A young Pimpe, a very ſucking-pig Pimpe! What an Age is this, when children play at ſuch great game! So young, ſo forward!

lg.l: The young and the old mun too't, mun too't,
The young and the old mun to it;
The young ones will learn to do't, to do't,
And the Oldforget not to do it.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: This Infant piece of Impudence ama●es me. Prithee what art thou? or whom doſt thou ſerve, or broke for.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: As delicate a piece of Woman-fleſh as ever Mortall laid lip to. O ſhe is all Venus! And, to come cloſe to you, ſhee wants a Phyſician. You are one I take it: I am a foole elſe.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I am catch'd? This habite will betray me. What is ſhee, I ſay.

lg.l: O ſhe is, ſhe is a matchleſſe piece,
Though all the world may wooe her;
Nor golden ſhowre, nor golden fleece,
Is price enough to do her.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: For what wants ſhe a Phyſitian?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p:
For what you pleaſe, when you come to her. Sir, upon my life, ſhee's free from any Diſeaſe, but the Counterfeits. Will you know all Sir? ſhe wants a wi●e mans counſell to aſſiſt her in getting a Husband. I take hold of you for that wiſe man, ſhee relyes upon my Election. Will you go Sir? Tis in an exceeding civill
houſe; a preciſe one, indeed. Know you not Mr. Lin|ſey Woolſey?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Not at his houſe?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir. At his very houſe. All the wiſe wenches i'the Town will thwack to ſuch Sanctuaries, when the times are troubleſome, and Troopers trace the ſtreets in terror.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Prithee, what call'ſt thy Miſtres?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: There ſhe lies Sir, by the name of Miſtreſſe Tryman; a rich young Corniſh Widdow; though ſhe was borne in Clearken-well; and was never halfe a dayes Journey from Bride well in her life. Her Father was a Pinn-maker—Sings.

lg.l: Along along, where the Gallants throng
By twenties, away the Widow to carry:
But let them tarry: For ſhee will carry
Twenty, before that one ſhe will Marry.

sp.p: Will you along Sir?

lg.l: Tis but a weak ingagement: yet Ile goe;
Needleſſe are feares, where Fortunes are ſo low.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Widdow! what is ſhee? or of whence?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A luſtie young wench, they ſay: A Corniſh Girle; able to wraſtle downe ſtronger Chines then any of ours.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: But how is ſhe purſ'd, Jack? Is ſhe ſtrong that way?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Prettie well for a younger Brother; worth 7 or 8 thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: How man!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You are a married man, and cannot Rivall me▪ I would not elſe be ſo open to you.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I ſweare Ile help thee all I can. How didſt find her out?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I have intelligence, that never failes me, ſhee came to town neither but very lately; and lodg'd at Mr. Wolſeys.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Who, Linſy wolſie, the Hermaphroditicall Dra|per! That's a precious No●t-headed Raſcall. Hee'll goe neare to ayme at her himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Like enough. He may aime at her: But ſhee will be hit by none but a Gentleman, that I heare 〈…〉 Oh ſhee has a fierce Ambition to a Ladyſhip, though her late Husband was a Tanner.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Tanner, well Jack, cake heed how thou ven|tur●ſt on her to make her a Gentlewoman: She will kill ●hee at her Husbands occupation before thou wile be able to make her Hide gentle. Thou w●●● find a tough peece of Curriers work on her. Look who here is.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Truly▪ Mr. Toby Sneakup, me thinks I find an alteration in my ſelfe already.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Nay, I told you; would you but give your Mind to it, you would be a Gentleman quickly.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: How's this? let's ſtand aſide a●●tle.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure, hee's about to turne himſelfe into a Gentleman to winne to the Widdow!

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: And what a Tutor he has pickt out to inſtruct him!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Me thinks I love the name of a Gentleman a great deale better then I did.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: But could you find in your heart to lend a Gentleman a ſcore of Angells, Mr. Wolſey, on his word?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Uhm—I is not gone ſo farre upon me yet.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh, but it m●ſt though, I know it. A Citizen can never be a Gentleman, till he has lent all, or almoſt all his money to Gentlemen. What a while it was ere the rich Joyners ſon was a Gentleman? when I my ſelfe was a Gentleman firſt, my mony did ſo burne in my Pockets, that it coſt me all that ever I had, or could borrow, or ſteal from my Mother.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: But Mr. Toby, a man may be a Countrey Gentleman, and keep his money, may he not?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You ſee Sir, This Widdow is remov'd from the Countrey into the City, to avoyd the multiplicity of Country Gentlemen that were here ●uitors. Nay you muſt be a Citty Gallant; or a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I ſee no Courtiers, but are more apt to borrow, then to ●end.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I, thoſe that were born, or bred Courtiers I grant you, But to come to't at your yeares—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I can the ſooner learne. Your Courtier Sir, I pray.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ile tell you in a breife character was taught me. Speake nothing that you mean, performe nothing that you promiſe, pay nothing that you owe, flatter all a|bove you, ſcorne all beneath you, deprave all in pri|vate, praiſe all in publike; keepe no truth in your mouth, no faith in your heart; no health in your bones, no freindſhip in your mind, no modeſty in your eyes, no Religion in your conſcience; but eſpecially, no Money in your Purſe.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O that Article ſpoyles all.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: If you do, take heed of ſpending it on any thing but Panders, Puncks, and Fidlers; for that were moſt unfaſhionable.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, for your Courtly and Gentle|manlike inſtructions, and wiſh you grace to follow them: I have ſeen too fearfull an example lately in my neighbour Craſy, whoſe ſteps I liſt not trace; nor lend my Money to be laught at among my Neighbours. Fare you well Sir.—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Wolſie! Well met. How does your faire Gueſt at home, Mrs. Tryman?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How ſhould he come to the knowledge of her? Some of theſe Gallants will ſnatch her up, if I prevent not ſpee|dily.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why ſpeak you not Mr. Wolſie? How does the Widow?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Truly not well Sir. Whether it be wearineſſe of her journey, change of ayre, or dyet, or what I know not; ſomething has diſtemperd her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or Love, perhaps of you Mr. Wolſie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Me? Alaſſe, I look like no ſuch Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You may in a ſhort time.
Harke hither Mr. Wolſie.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We overheard you man: And I gueſt as much before.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tis very true Sir, ſhee is worth nine thouſand pound: But marry ſhe will not'but a Gentleman: And I think I have beat him off o'th condition, I have put him off o' that ſcent for ever, with a falſe character, Heaven and the Court forgive me.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thou haſt introth Boy: And on purpoſe to have her thy ſelfe, I perceive it.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: He does not. He's an Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Well, if I were a Batchelor, I ſhould envy thy wit, and thy fortune. Is ſhe very handſome?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: So ſo: You ſhall ſee wee'll make a ſhift with her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Wolſie, I would you had her with all my heart; you ſhall not want my good word and beſt wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Do you ſpeak this in earneſt Sir, or as you are a Courtier:

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: In earneſt I, and as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Then in earneſt, and as I am an honeſt man, I do not beleeve you. Mr. Toby Sneakup has told me what Gentlemen and Courtiers are, too lately.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Sneakup▪ well met.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Good Mr. Rufflit.

lg.l: Now faire Mayds lay downe my B●d,
And draw the Curtaines round:
Tell the World that I am dead,
And who hath given the wound,
Ah me poor Soul!
Alack for love I dye,
Then to the Sexton hie,
And cauſe the Bell to towle.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: O here he is! Mr. Wolſie, indeed my Maſter Wolſie, if ever you will ſee my Miſtres your Sweetheart alive, you muſt goe home preſently.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My Sweetheart!

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: I thinke ſhee is; and that in death ſhe will be ſo. I ſpeak by what ſhe ſayes, and others think.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tis the Widows Boy,

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Is ſhe ſicker then she was.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: O shee is even ſpeechleſſe, and calls for you exceedingly. I fetcht a Doctor to her, and he can do her no good. Maſter Sarpego has made her Will and all.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Has shee given me any thing?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Quickly goe and ſee Sir, you will come too late elſe, I am going to get the Bell to towle for her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Fare ye well Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tic. Ruff. Nay, wee'll along with you.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Sing.

lg.l: Did never truer heart
Out of the World depart,
Or cauſe the Bel to towle.

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: Enter in the Tryman, attended by Iſabell, Jone, Craſy, with an Ʋrinall.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: LOok up Miſtres.
Jo. Take a good heart, the worſt is paſt, feare not.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Reach the Bottle againe of Doctor Stephens water.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No no, apply more warme cloaths to her ſto|mack, there the matter lyes which ſends this diſtem|perature into her braine. Be of good cheer Gentle|woman.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Is Mr Wolſie there?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Nothing but Mr. Wolſie ever in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Pray Sir, how do you like her? I am much af|fraid of her.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Let me ſee, to night it will be full Moon. And ſhe ſcape the turning of the next Tyde, I will give her a gentle Vomit in the morning, that ſhall eaſe her ſto|mack of this conflux of venomous humours, and make her able to ſit a hunting Nag within this ſennight.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: A rare man ſure. And, I warrant, well ſeen in a Woman▪

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Well ſayd, ſpit out gently, ſtraine not your ſelfe too hard.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Agh—fagh.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Tis very well done. La'you. Her colour be|gins to come. Ile lay all my skill to a meſſe of Tewks|bury Muſtard, ſhee ſneezes thrice within theſe three houres—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Good Sir want nothing, that your skill ſhall approve neceſſary in this time of need. Good Wives and kinde Neighbours, I thanke you for your cares.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Is Mr. Wolſie there?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: She does nothing but call for you Sir, pray ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Where's Mr. Wolſie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Here Lady. How do you?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Then I am even well me thinks—agh—agh—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Shee's very farr gone I feare, how do you find her diſeaſe Sir?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p:
Dangerous enough Sir. For ſhee is ſicker in minde then in body. For I finde moſt plainely the ef|fects of a deep melancholly, falne through her diſtem|perature of paſſion upon her Liver; much diſordering, and withall waſting the vitals, leaving ſcarce matter for Phyſick to worke on. So that her minde receiving
the firſt hurt, muſt receive the firſt cure.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Agh agh ah—pagh fagh—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: So ſo: Straine not your ſelfe too hard. No hurt; ſo ſo.
Here's melancholly and choller both in plenty.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: He ſpeaks with great reaſon, me thinks, and to the purpoſe, I would I underſtood him.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Do you not know▪ Sir, any that has offended her by open injury, or unkindneſſe?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Alas Sir, no ſuch thing could happen ſince her coming hither.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Then, on my life, tis Love that afflicts her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh oh uh oh—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I have toucht her to the quick. I have found her diſeaſe, and that you may prove the abler Doctor in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Who I? Alas I beleeve no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Mr. Wolſie, Mr. Wolſie.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Here he is Lady. Pray ſpeak your minde to him. Muſt I pull you to her? Here he is. What do you ſay to him? Pray ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh no, no no no—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: She hath ſomething troubles her that con|cernes onely you. Pray take her by the hand, do as I intreat you. Lady we will go, and leave you in private awhile, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray do. O but do not, pray do not.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Do you perceive nothing in this paſſion of hers?
How does ſhe feel your hand?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O, ſhe does ſo quiddle it, ſhake it, and gripe it!

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: You are then the man Sir, the happy man. For ſhe ſhall recover ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Who I? Alack a day.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: What will you have me dye inteſtate. Is not my Will made, as I directed?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Where are you Mr. Sarpego, with the Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Ad manum. Sweet Buds of Generoſity, for|beare you may Admirare, at the abundance here ſpecified: But not find a Legacie bequeath'd among you

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We expect nothing.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I only wiſh your health, Lady; and that it may, or might have been my happineſs to ſue to you for Love; as I do now to the higheſt power for Life.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Would I were married to her, as ſhee is; and twere but for an hower, I car'd not. Had my mother been but acquainted with her, before ſhee fell ſick, here had been a match!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O Dij immortales! A rich Widdow ſhall have Suiters on her Death-bed.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Good Sir, It is too late to ſpeak of theſe things. I only crave and wish your prayers in your abſence: This place can yield no pleaſure to you I know. Mr. Wolſey, pray your hand againe: I could be even content to live me thinks, if I had but ſuch a man as you to my Huh, uh, uh, uh.—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: By your leave. Pray by your leave. Help Women. Beare up her Body a little. Bow it forwards. So, ſpeak to her, Sr. Good Lady drink of this Cordyal.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How do you now forſooth?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: What now shee is drinking—Now ſpeake Sir, you or no man muſt do her good.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How do you forſooth?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Well ſaid Sir, ſpeak chearfully to her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How dee doe? how dee doe, Miſtris Tryman How iſt now, ha?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Very comfortably ſpoken!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I, was it not?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Alas ſhee cannot ſpeak. I'll call my Neigh|bour Miſtres Sneakup. If any body can make her ſpeak, 'tis ſhee.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I'll call my Mother for you. Shee will make her ſpeak, if ſhee have but a word left in her belly—Maſſe here ſhee comes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How comes it Mr. Wolſey, that you have a Gentlewoman ſick in your houſe, and not ſend for me? Let me feel her hand. Alaſſe ſhe is ſhrewdly diſtem|per'd. When had ſhee a ſtoole Sir, Prithee Daughter ſtep home to my Cloſet, and bring the Viall of—my owne Water, which ſtands next to my blew Vel|vet Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: That's my Doctor was with me to day

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Shee's a young Gentlewoman; may have many Children yet, let me note her eyes: I finde nothing there. When did you ſee her water Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: What Devill ſent this fury among us?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: In troth I beſhrew you, Mr. Wolſey, you ſent not for me, but I hope I come not too late. Pluck up a Womens heart, you ſhall find a good Neighbour of me.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I will thank you in my Will. I ſhall not live to thank you otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Alas talk not of your will. You ſhall have time enough to think of that many yeares hence.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I tell her ſo, Lady, yet ſhee calls for it ſtill.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray let me ſee it, that I may ſigne it. Ʋh Ʋh—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Lord how my Daughter ſtayes. Good Sir Andrew Ticket! worthy Mr. Rufflit! My Sonne To|bias is highly honor'd in your noble Acquaintance, and Courtly converſation.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We rather hold our ſelves dignified, in being his indear'd Companions.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I aſſure you Mother, we are the three of the Court.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: I moſt intirely thank you for him. And I do beſeech you make your ſelves no ſtrangers to my poor houſe. Wee are alone; can give but light enter|tainement, my Daughter and I; ſince my Sonne Cra|ſies misfortune drave him from us—
O welcome Daughter—I beſeech you noble Sirs eſtrange not your ſelves to us, your Servants.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Pox o'your Complement.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Give me the Viall Daughter. Take up the La|dy. Taſt of this. It is a Compoſition of mine owne diſtilling.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, umh—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well done. Nay it will make you break wind, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: By the ſervice I owe you ſweet Miſtres, tis un|fained. My Wife deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
As I can beſt witneſſe; And feares you enjoy not the libertie of a Woman, ſince your Husbands de|parture.
Your Brother having promis'd too, to con|duct you to Court.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: It is confeſt, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Where the beſt entertainment a poore Ladyes chamber can afford, ſhall expect you.

sp.speaker: Ioſ
sp.p: I ſhall embrace it.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Sfoot, tis time to part you—Miſtres, I be|ſeech your help, joyn'd with your vertuous Mothers.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: You forget the young man, that can Dance Write, and keep Counſell.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I forget you not Lady. But I wiſh you to be|ware of theſe Courtiers, till I tell you what they are:

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if this Doctor be not of her ſmock Counſell.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How is it now, good heart?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Much enlightned, I thank Heaven and you. Now, pray, read Sir my Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: In Dei nomine. Amen.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: O let us heare the Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I Iane Tryman of Knockers hole, in the County of Cornwall, Widdow, Sick in Body, but whole in Mind, and of perfect memory, do make my laſt Will and Teſtament, in Manner and Forme following.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: As for the Manner and Forme tis no matter. To the Legacies, briefly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hum hum. Imprimis, A Dole of Bread to be given to the Poore of this Parish—five pound.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Stay. This I intreat of you Mr. Wolſey, that whether I live or dye, this Dole may be given to mor|row. It was the Charge of my Mother to ſee it done; Saying, it was better to take the Prayers of the Poore with me, then leave them to be ſent after.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: It shall be done: and you, I hope, shall ſee it.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
To Mr. Sarpego, the Writer hereof, A Mourn|ing
Gown, and forty pound, to Preach at the Fune|rall.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How! forty pound?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Di boni! No. Tis forty shillings. Item to my Nephew, Sir Marmaduke Trevaugh an of St. Mine|ver, one thouſand pound in Gold. Item to my Ne|phew Mr. Francis Trepton, one thouſand pound in Gold. Item to my Kinſman, Sir Stephen Leggleden, I do forgive two thouſand pound, for which his Lands are Mortgaged to me. Item to his Daughter, my God-daughter Iane Leggleden, five hundred pound in money; my beſt Baſon and Ewer; two ſilver Flaggon Pots, and three ſilver and gilt ſtanding Cups. Item to the poore of the Pariſh of Knockers-hole, ten pound, and forty pound towards the reparation of their Church. Item to Mr. Linſey wolſey the Ring, which was my Wedding Ring, and fifty other Rings, with ſeverall ſtones in my Trunck, in his houſe, valued at two hundred and fifty pounds. Item to all his ſer|vants, and to the Women that attended me in my ſickneſſe, five pound a piece.

sp.speaker: Jone.
sp.p: Now the Lord receive her to his mercy.

sp.speaker: Iſa
sp.p: My Legacy will ſave her life; for never any body dyed yet, that bequeathed me any thing.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Item, to my Page Jeffery Crack forty pound. And all my other Servants ten pound a peice. Item to my Neece Barbara Tredrite five hundred pound; my ſecond Baſon and Ewer, a dozen of ſilver Diſhes, and four dozen of ſilver Spoones. Laſtly, all the reſt of my Lands, Jewels, Plate, Money, Debts, Moveables and Unmoveables, to my dear and loving Brother, Sir Gre|gory Flamsted, whom I make my full Executor. In cujus rei teſtimonium, &c. This is the briefe of it.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p:
Tis well. Onely add to it—Ʋh—A Gold Chaine alſo in my Trunk to this vertuous Gentlewo|man.
And another Chaine, that is there of Pearle, to her Daughter. To this learned Doctor twenty pound. And to the Gentlemen which have viſited me, for them and their freinds an hundred pound to be ſpent in a Banckquet.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hoc nihil refert. I muſt write all over againe then.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Do ſo then. And make your forty shillings five pound.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Gratias vel ingentes ago. It ſhall be done—

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Now Mr. Wolſie, and your vertuous Neighbour here, I intreat, that when I have ſigned this Will, that you keep it til my Brother comes to Town. This Doctor shall direct you in all. And that he may be the better able ſo to do, I deſire you all that I may a while be private with him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Are they all gone?
Now Mr. Doctor, what think you of the ſick Widow?
Has she done her part hitherto?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Beyond my expectation! Better then I for a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: You are right. And I am even the ſame for a Widow as you for a Doctor. Do not I know you? Yes good Mr. Craſy. I dare truſt you, becauſe you muſt truſt me. Therefore know, that I the rich Widow am no better, then a Lady that muſt live by what I beare about me. The vulgar tranſlation you know, but let them ſpeak their pleaſure, I have no Lands, and ſince I am borne, muſt be kept, I may make the beſt of my owne, and if one member maintaine the whole body, what's that to any one?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I collected as much by your young Whiskin that brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: It was by my direction that he did ſo. And, by my Inſtructions, he has had an Eye upon you in all your diſguiſes ever ſince your pretended ●ourney out of Towne. Nay ſtartle not, nor muſe at my acquain|tance with you: I have had you in my Purlews, be|fore you were a Freeman: And will hereafter give you certaine tokens of it. In the mean time, if you comply with me, you can be no loofer by it. I am grown weary of my old courſe; and would faine, by wiſer, do my ſelfe good, before Age or Diſeaſes make it too late.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will work cloſe and friendly with thee. Therefore ſay, this rich Cockſcombe is thine owne. O here comes your Pigg-wiggen.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: He is of Counſell, and one of us. He is indeed my Brother, and has been one of the true blew Boyes of the Hoſpitall; one of the ſweet ſingers to the City Funeralls with a two penny loafe under his arme.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Well: He never ſung to the wheele in Saint Brides Nunnery yonder.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Nay Jeff, be not angry; thou haſt ſung to the Organs I know, till fearing their downfall, thou be|tookſt thy ſelfe into my more certaine ſervice. All freinds, good Jeff.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we muſt all agree, and be linckt in Covenant together.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: By Indenture Tripartite, and't pleaſe you, like Subtle, Doll, and Face.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Witty Jeff. I cannot ſee which can be ſpar'd from the reſt, leaſt the whole trade break.

lg.l: Then let us be freinds, and moſt freindly agree.
The Pimp and the Punck and the Doctor are three,
That cannot but thrive, when united they be.
The Pimp brings in cuſtome, the Punck ſhee gets treaſure,
Of which the Phyſitian is ſure of his meaſure,
For work that ſhe makes him in ſale of her pleaſure.
For which, when ſhe failes by diſeaſes or paine,
The Doctor new Vamps and upſets her againe.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Thou art a brave Lad, and in the high way of preferment.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Not the high Holborne way, I hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: And for you Damſell, as I ſayd before, ſay to your ſelfe, the Match is yours.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I mean to ſay, and know it ſhortly. Some three dayes hence all may be compleated. Now draw the Curtaines; and follow your affaires, while I put on my ſick Face againe. Ʋh, uh, uh.

div.stage: They put in the Bed, and withdraw all. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene II.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: NOw could I Accoſt that Catlinarian Traytor, that defea|ted me of my ten pound, I have a precogitated Ora|tion ſhould make him ſuſpend himſelfe. But Abiit, e|vaſit, erupit. Or if the rich Widow would have dyed, there had been a ſupply. But ſhe is nearer a Nuptiall, then a Funerall: And hopeleſſe Sarpego, that ſhould wed, has not to furniſh him to his intent, Vae mihi mi|ſero nec Aurum, nec Argent—tum! Here comes my Beatitude.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O, are you here Sir? I was to ſeek you. My old Miſtreſſe would ſpeak with you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: My Legitimate Spouſe, when is our day of con|junction?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Our day of conjunction? Mary faugh Good|man Fiſte. Our day of conjunction?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Did you not once vow you did love me?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Did not you once ſwear you had money?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hic jacet, I am now but a dead man.

div.stage: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Craſie—like a Court-Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: O where's Mr. Sarpego? Fortunate Mr. Sarpe|go? Venerable Mr. Sarpego? O Sir, you are made. Never thinke under right worſhipfull. Imagine nothing beneath Damaſque Gownes, Velvet Jackets, Satten Sleeves, Silk Nightcaps, two Pages and a Footcloth.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: The Son of Phoebus rectifie your Brain-pan.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Indeed, and't ſhall pleaſe your Worſhip, it is—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: It is! What is it? You will be ſpeaking, will you? And your Wife in preſence, will you? you ſhew your bringing up. Maſter Sarpego, bleſſe the time that ever you knew the Progeny of the Sneakups: my wor|ſhipfull Son and Heire apparent hath preferred you to be the young Prince his Tutor. Here's Mr. Holywater, a Gentleman; of place, a Courtier; of Office, is ſent for you.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Right fortunately-learned Sir. So paſſionate|ly doth his Grace approve the Language, Literature, and Haviour of your ſometimes Pupill, Maſter To|bias Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Umh.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: That I was, with all expedition, commanded to intreat your inſtant Attendance.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Umh Umh—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: 'Tis even ſo Sir; You are like to poſſeſs a Princes eare; you may be in place, where you may ſcorn your foes; countenance your friends; cheriſh vertue, controule vice, and deſpiſe fortune: Yes ſure ſhall you Sir. And (which I had almoſt forgot) your old Pupill intreats you to ſend him by me the ten pound he lent you: An od ten pound, that he may be furniſh'd with the more ſeemly Complements to con|duct you to his Grace.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Quid nunc?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Whiſt Mr. Sarpego. Let not your poverty be read in your face. Here's ten pieces. Bear it as your own payment: You talk of ten pound for my Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O, an od driblet. Here, Friend, I uſe not to carry Silver: Convey it in Gold.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I hope, dear Love, you will not forget your affection to me now.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Poor Maid, I will prefer thee to ſcratch my head; make my Bed; wash my Shirt, pick my toes, and evacuate my Chamberpot. I will inſtantly procure mee attire, fitting my fortune, and attend the Grace of Court—

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Now am I but a dead woman.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I am much griev'd for't. It was your ſonnes much labouring, that Mr. Craſie was ſent for, to ſell his Grace ſome Jewells: But ſince his fortunes are ſo ſunk that he hides his head, I can but lament his loſſe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Shall I tell you Sir, (pray you husband ſtand a|ſide;) My Son-in-Law Craſie is not now worth—his very wife. We hop'd he would have prov'd a crafty Merchant, and he prov'd an honeſt man, a Begger (if I chance to ſpeak above your capacity, I pray tell me of
it) And as I ſaid, when I perceiv'd he began to melt, and that every ſtranger abuſed him; I, having ſome wit, fell too, and moſt cozen'd him my ſelf. I look'd for my daughters good: And ſo betwixt us, found the trick to get, or ſteale from him two Jewells of good deep value, being indeed the main of his reſt of Fortune. Now Sir, I come to you.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I, now you come to the point.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Right Sir: For there is no woman, though she uſe never ſo many by-words, but yet in the end she will come to the point. Now Sir, I having theſe Jewells, will ſend them by my husband. A poor eaſie weak man, as you ſee; but very obedient in truth—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: By your husband.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Yes, do you mark? By my husband. But now note my wit: His Grace knows not Craſie: My huſ|band, habited like a Citizen, shall take the name of Craſie upon him; offer his Jewells to the Prince; you shall preſent them; praiſe them and raiſe them: His Grace payes; my husband returns; and we will share. Do you approve?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Nay admire.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Away then. No Complement among good wits; but away. Come your ways hi|ther, good man; Put off your hat; Make a leg; Look ſimply. Why ſo! Pish, ne're tell me: He will make a rare Citizen. I have Jewells for you to carry to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes forſooth, I'le carry them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
La! you are ſo quick! I have charg'd you not to shoot your bolt, before you underſtand your mark. And you shall carry them like a Citizen; call your ſelf Craſie; ſell them at my price; and now caſt no further. You ſee the limits of your underſtanding. Now Sir, how will you bear your ſelf to his Grace?
How behave your ſelfe at Court?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I hope I am not too wiſe to learne.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why, that was well ſpoken. Modeſt miſtruſt is the firſt ſtep to knowledge. Remember that ſen|tence. Now mark. I will inſtruct you: When you come at the Court gate, you may neither knocke nor piſſe. Do you mark? You go through the Hall co|ver'd; through the great Chamber cover'd; through the Preſence bare; through the Lobby cover'd; through the Privy Chamber bare; through the Privy Lobby cover'd; to the Prince bare.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I'le doe't I warrant you. Let me ſee. At the Court gate neither knock nor make water. May not a man break wind?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Umh, yes: but (like the Exchequer payment) ſomewhat abated.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Through the great Chamber bare.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Cover'd.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Cover'd? Well: Through the Preſence co|ver'd.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Bare.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Bare? I will put all dowe in my Table-book, and con it by the way.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well thought on. Something he has in him like my husband! But now you come before the brow of Royalty. Now for your carriage there Sir: Sup|poſe me the Prince. Come in, and preſent. Here ſits the Prince. There enters the Jeweller. Make your ho|nors. Let me ſee you do it handſomly.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes, now I come in; make my three legs—And then—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Kneele.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes; and ſay—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Nay, that I know not.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Grace, I have certain Jewells to preſent to your liking.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Grace, I have certain Jewels to preſent to your liking.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Is this Craſie, that had wont to ſerve me with Jewells? It is that honeſt man, ſo pleaſe your High|neſſe. That's for M. Holywater, the by-flatterer to ſpeak. You are a Cuekoldly Knave, Sirrah, and have often a|buſed me with falſe and deceitfull ſtones.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: My ſtones are right, ſo pleaſe your Ex|cellence.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why that was well, Very well. I perceive there is a certain infection taken with lying with a wo|man that hath a good wit. I finde it by my husband. Come, I'le diſguiſe you, and away to Court in|ſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Truly wife, I fear J ſhall be diſcover'd among the Gallants preſently.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: No, no, A fool is never diſcover'd among mad|men.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p:
WEll Dol, (that thou ſaiſt is thy name) though J had forgotten thee, J proteſt. About London-wall was it (ſaiſt thou?) Well, J can|not but highly commend thy wiſdom in this, that ſo
well haſt mended thy election; from being a foun|tain of aches, bald brows, and broad plaſters, thus to remember thy Creation.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I did conſider, and I thinke rightly, what I was; and that men that lov'd my uſe, lov'd it but to loath me: Therefore I chang'd my ſelf into this ſhape of a demure, innocent Countrey Widdow, that had ſcarce beauty enough to be tempted, but not wit e|nough to be naught; and quite forſook the path I trod in, and betook me to this private courſe of co|zenage.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: But all my wonder is at the means, how thou gott'ſt into this houſe and reputation. And to be held a woman of ſuch an eſtate.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: That ſhall bee made plaine to you here|after.
Now Brother Geffrey, where left you M Wolſie?

sp.speaker: Crack.
sp.p: Among the Mercers, ſo troubled, as if all the Sattin in Cheapſide were not enough to make you a wedding Gowne. He is over-joy'd that his happy day is at hand; and I over-heard him invite one ſpe|ciall friend to his Nuptialls. He cannot contain him|ſelf. On a ſudden he fell a ſinging, O ſhee's a dainty Widdow. O are you come Sir, in your new ſhape? Dos not that beard fit you handſomly? Thank my ac|quaintance with the Players.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I thinke thou art acquainted any way, to ſet out knavery.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: If you can perform your part as well, 'tis well. Heark, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: VVhere are you ſweet Widdow? Look you, Look you: How do you like theſe patterns?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Gentleman has a Letter to you: He tells me it imports the making, or the undo|ing of his deareſt friend.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: From whom, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your ſometimes neighbor Sir, M: Craſy.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: It ſhall take effect, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: He ſcratches his head, though.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: He had as liefe part with his blood as his money.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: M. Craſy writes to me for thirty pound; the value of a Ring I had of him. I grant I am to pay threeſcore at my day of Marriage. But we are all mortall. And who knowes whether I ſhall live till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: If not, Sir, your Bond is due to night: For it is equally payable at your hour of death.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O, but ſuch payments never trouble a man. What the eye ſees not—

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Are you in Bonds, M. Woolſie, for your day of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Only for this ſixty pound. 'Tis for that Ring you weare, and I gave you upon our Contract. 'Tis worth thirty pound ready mony.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Then when you are married, you may ſay you paid the reſt for your wife. Pray Sir make even ſuch reckonings before you wed. It will ſhew nobly in you towards your poor Creditor, and be a ſpeciall argument of your love to me, your wife. Pray diſ|charge it, I ſhall not think you love me elſe.

Heark you Sir, if you will take thirty pound in full
payment, and give me in my Bond, here is your mony. 'Tis your beſt courſe. Alas, I am an unlikely fellow for wedlock. What woman, thinke you, would beſtow her ſelf upon me, a ſtale Batchellor, unhandſome and poor—not worth above ſix or ſeven thouſand pound? Do; take thirty pound.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: If you pleaſe to be friend Mr. Craſy but wich thirty pound, Ile ſet it receiv'd upon the Bond. Here it is. And he ſhall demand no more till it be due.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray Sir pay it all, and take in your Bond. You ſhall be married within theſe two dayes; to morrow, if you pleaſe: VVhat uſe will your money yeeld you for a night? Pray pay it. In truth I'le pay it elſe. 'Tis but threeſcore pound.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Saiſt thou ſo, Sweetheart. Come Sir. Come in and tell your money—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: And thank you too, good M. Linſie VVolſie, that knew ſo well, a bargaine was a bargaine, and would not part with your money to be laugh'd at a|mong your neighbours. I would heartily now, if I could intend it. But I muſt purſe your money, and then about my Court affairs. This wench I am in|finitely beholden to. She remembers ſome old curte|ſie that I have forgotten. Perhaps I pidled with her when I was Prentice.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: THis is the Preſence. I am much amaz'd, or ſtupified, that Mr. Tobias Sneakup, my quon|dam Pupill, attends not my Conduct! Ha! So in|ſtant was his Grace, his importunity to enjoy me, that although I purchaſed the loan of Cloaths, yet I had not vacation, nor indeed variety to ſhift my ſhirt. And now I come to Court, I feel certain little Cattell of infamous generation about me, that do moſt inſeparably haunt me. Now if (when the Prince ſurveyes me) any of them being ſtrangers here, ſhould peep to behold ſtrange ſights, and his Grace perceive them, what ſhould I anſwer?—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: O, my glorified Pedant in his moſt naturall ſtrut!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I will ſay it was by influence of the heavens; or, to appear the more perfect Courtier at the firſt daſh, I will ſay, that though my outſide were glorious, yet of purpoſe I left my inſide lowſie.
Sed, O Dii! Quem video? nonne Mr. Sneakup?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: See my worſhipfull Father-in-Law! Now the Woodcocks ſhoot into the glade.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray ye peace, you muſt not know me.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O monſtrum horrendum! May not you and I know one another?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray go home, and ask my wife.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Mr. Craſie. Is not one Mr. Craſie here?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes Sir. Here is Mr. Craſie for a need Sir.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Well done: Be bold Sir. Let not your diſſi|mulation be read in your eyes. You know me; give me the Jewells.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Let me alone to preſent them to his Grace, and praiſe them, before you are call'd.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Will you do ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Yes; For you know I muſt not ſeem to in|deare them before your face: For that would ſmell rank of correſpondency.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: You ſay right Sir.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: But betwixt us both wee'l make a ſhift to cheat him. Stay you here. I will returne inſtantly. O Mr. Sarpego! Your Pupill will come and conduct you pre|ſently.

lg.l: Thus ſometimes, by deceit, deceit is known:
'Tis honeſt craft, by wit to get ones own.—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: My Quondam Pedagogue!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: My Nuper Alumnus! Come, preſent me to the Grace of Greatneſs. I am ready; behold I am approach'd according to thy intreats, to approve thy praiſe, and mine own perfection. Set on: His Grace ſhall ſee that we can ſpeake true Latin, and conſtrue L●dovicus vives: Go, ſet on.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Sir. Upon my troth, I tooke you for Mr. Sarpego, my learned Tutor. He is very like him; Is he not Gentlemen? But now I come to my ſelfe againe, I remember this was never his walke, nor theſe his cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sent you not a Nuntius, or a Meſſenger for me, intimating, that it was his Grace his inſtant deſire, to entertain me as his Inſtructor?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Alas, he has over-ſtudied himſelf! You were beſt let blood in time Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sent I not you, by the ſame meſſenger, your ten pound?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My ten pound? Ha, ha ha: I would laugh i faith, if you could bob me off with ſuch payment.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure Sir, you uſe ſome Dormitaries. Beſt ſhave your head, and 'noint it with Oyl of Roſes.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Father! Father!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray peace ſon. The plot will be diſcover'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The plot? what plot?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: The Jewells are ſent in, What, I am Mr. Cra|ſie now, you know. I ſhall be ſent for in to his Grace inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Midſummer Moon! Midſummer Moon!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: In very truth ſon, hit as 'twill, I ſay we are beholding to Mr. Holywater.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Heaven not bleſſe me, if I underſtand not the Baboons mumpings better then your ſpeech. You are more dark then Delphos. What Holywater?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Why the Gentleman, you know, you ſent to bring M. Craſie to ſerve his Grace with Jewells.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Father, Heaven pardon me: For ſure I have a great deſire to call you Cockſcomb. I ſent no man; nor is there any ſo ſtiled as Holywater about the Court.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Do you not want ſleep ſir?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or have you not ſeen a ſpirit ſir?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Or have you not over-mus'd, or over-thought your ſelfe, as wee doubt Mr. Sarpego, here, has done?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Or has not my mother over-beaten you, fa|ther? You may tell me.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Son, I am not ſo very a foole, but I perceive I am made a ſtark Aſſe. Oh ſonne, thy father is co|zen'd; and thy mother will beat me indeed, unleſſe your charity conceal me in the Court here, till her fu|ry be over.

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.p: Hee ſhall ſtay at my Wives Cham|ber.

sp.speaker: Rufflit.
sp.p: And there inſtruct us in the paſſages of this cozenage.

sp.speaker: Tob.
